tossups.question: A dog named Snowball was widely cited in fundraising appeals during this event and led to the passage of the PETS Act. Vann R. Newkirk II's podcast about this event opens by describing a man named Richard on Last Island in 1856. A Syrian-American painter's struggles due to this event are told in Dave Eggers's nonfiction book Zeitoun. In this event's aftermath, five police officers were found guilty of covering up a fatal shooting on (*) Danziger Bridge. For crimes done during this event, the operators of St. Rita's Nursing Home were charged with 34 counts of negligent homicide. This event forced an NBA team to temporarily relocate to Oklahoma City. A bureaucrat nicknamed Brownie was infamously told he was doing a "heck of a job" handling this event for FEMA by George W. Bush. For 10 points, name this hurricane that devastated New Orleans.
tossups.answer: Hurricane Katrina [anti-prompt on answers like the levees failing in New Orleans or the flooding of New Orleans; prompt on hurricanes]

tossups.question: VisitLeicester.com ("Visit Lester dot com") claims that the British city's celebration of this holiday along Belgrave Road is the biggest in Europe. This holiday coincides with an increased number of injuries and deaths from fulzadi. A festive period that ends with this holiday is now kicked off with the invented e-commerce holiday of Big Billion Days, which in 2020 had a lot of payments made via Paytm ("pay-T-M"). In 2017, one country's Supreme Court banned the sale of devices like the "garland" and the "snake tablet" near the capital in the leadup to this holiday to reduce (*) smog and burns from fireworks. This holiday coincides with the biggest sales day of the year for Flipkart. On this holiday, one country's stock exchange opens for only one hour during the period of Muhurat. Sweets are typically purchased on this festival's second day, Choti. For 10 points, name this Indian festival of lights.
tossups.answer: Diwali [or Divali; or Deepawali; or Dīpāvali; accept things like the first day of Diwali]

tossups.question: A 2019 Times series on these products contrasted their ubiquity in Kibera, Nairobi, with their reduction in Denmark, and noted the failure of their producer Melinta. A 2015 CDDEP report on these products tracked the consequences of their use in 46 countries with an index created by Ramanan Laxminarayan that tops out at 71 for India. A 2019 UN report warned of a "silent tsunami" of (*) 10 million annual deaths if these products run out. In the 2019 AWaRe Classification Database, some of these products are "reserves" of "last resort." "Stewardship" of these products entails C&S testing that measures minimum inhibitory concentrations to select narrow-spectrum options. Farmers promote livestock weight gain by feeding sub-therapeutic levels of these drugs, reducing the efficacy of types like cephalosporins. For 10 points, the overuse of what drugs causes the evolution of resistant bacteria?
tossups.answer: antibiotics [accept specific antibiotics or classes of antibiotics; accept antibiotic resistance; accept antimicrobials or antimicrobial resistance or AMR; accept antifungals; prompt on drugs or pharmaceuticals or similar answers before "drugs"] (C&S is culture and sensitivity testing. The CDDEP is the Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy.)

tossups.question: Christopher Schaberg wrote a book on the "end" of these places as "sites of excitement" due to the rise of smartphones. After a buying spree, a French company called Vinci is now the largest private owner of these places in Europe. The “Monster,” a faulty smoke-extraction system, delayed the opening of one of these places in Europe for nearly a decade. A program called CAPPS, which is widely used at these places, has been criticized as (*) "theater" by people like Eric Levenson. A recently expanded place of this kind includes a mall with a rain vortex and the "world's tallest indoor waterfall." One of these complexes designed by Norman Foster, which was projected to cost 13 billion dollars and would have served Mexico City, was cancelled by the AMLO administration. For 10 points, name these transport facilities that are often too small for Airbus A380s.
tossups.answer: airports [accept The End of Airports] (CAPPS is the Computer-Assisted Passenger Prescreening System.)

tossups.question: Humphreys and Finlay's essay on the technological narratives of this event focused on the quest to complete a TD-SCDMA 3G network on time. Prior to this event, rival groups threw bottled water at each other over a dispute involving Carrefour ("car-FOOR") grocery stores. The master plan for this event was overseen by the son and namesake of Albert Speer. Human rights protesters frequently interrupted this event's leadup, the "Journey of Harmony." Preparatory celebrations for this event were postponed after an (*) earthquake killed 69,000 people. On alternating days prior to this event, passenger cars were prohibited from taking to the streets to improve air quality. Buildings constructed for this event included the Water Cube and the Bird's Nest stadium. For 10 points, name this athletic competition in China's capital.
tossups.answer: 2008 Beijing Summer Olympics [or 2008 Summer Olympics; or Games of the XXIX Olympiad; prompt on China Olympics; prompt on Summer Olympics]

tossups.question: A young version of this person declares "I am not even awakened yet" after being asked to "come to God and be saved" in a film often compared to the director's earlier film The House of Mirth. Craig and the chimp Elijah watch a giant puppet of this person on TV near the start of Being John Malkovich. A show about this person features a bonkers cameo by Jason Mantzoukas, who voices a talking bee during an opium trip. In a 2018 comedy, prim lectures given by Amy Seimetz's character are juxtaposed with this title character's sex scenes. Cynthia Nixon plays this woman in the (*) Terence Davies biopic ("bio-pic") A Quiet Passion, which depicts her brother Austin's affair with Mabel Todd. Hailee Steinfeld plays this woman in an Apple TV+ drama where she has a queer relationship with her sister-in-law Susan Gilbert. For 10 points, what poet inspired Madeleine Olnek's film Wild Nights with Emily?
tossups.answer: Emily Dickinson [or Emily Elizabeth Dickinson; prompt on Emily]

tossups.question: Some of the only visual evidence of this conflict comes from children's drawings collected by a researcher who goes by the pseudonym Anna Schmidt. This is the most recent event featured in the documentary Watchers of the Sky. A magazine essay on this conflict by the future author of The Education of an Idealist describes how some participants carried leather boxes called hijaab to protect them from bullets. A group active in this conflict paid recruits 116 dollars if they already owned a camel and faced off against rivals such as the (*) Justice and Equality Movement. Musa Hilal of the Um Jalul clan recruited troops during this conflict for a group whose name means "a man with a gun on a horse." During this conflict, many members of the Masalit and Zaghawa peoples fled to refugee camps in Chad. For 10 points, Janjaweed militias were active in what North African genocide?
tossups.answer: Darfur genocide [or Darfur war; prompt on Second Sudanese Civil War]

tossups.question: In the review essay "Scar," one author from this country documented her sexual assault in fifth grade. A novel from this country narrated by a male psychiatrist includes numerous footnotes on gender inequality and centers on a woman dubbed a "mum-roach" for drinking coffee in the middle of the day. That novel, whose title roughly translates to "Jane Doe, Born 1982," was the first million-copy seller here since a 2008 novel about a 69-year-old character who goes missing at a subway station. An author took this country by storm with that novel, (*) Please Look After Mom. "Mongolian Mark" names the second section of a novel from this country in which the protagonist slits her wrists after being forced to consume pork. Deborah Smith translated this country's 2007 novel The Vegetarian. For 10 points, name this country home to authors Han Kang ("hahn kahng") and Ko Un.
tossups.answer: South Korea [or Republic of Korea; or ROK; prompt on Korea]

tossups.question: Support for this "generic" concept arises from "a largely subliminal elective affinity" according to Roger Griffin's book about its "nature." A 1995 essay argues that this "syncretistic" title concept fosters "obsession with a plot" and "makes heroism the norm." It's not grief, but this concept proceeds through five stages, with Stage One common to most countries, according to a 2007 book on its "anatomy" by Robert O. Paxton. A square-shaped, arch-filled building celebrating 20 years of this concept in the marble (*) EUR ("eh-oor") district now houses Fendi's HQ. Fourteen features like "action for action's sake" and "the cult of tradition" typify this concept's eternal "Ur-" form according to Umberto Eco. A revived "neo-" form of this ideology includes the Third Position embraced by Forza Nuova and CasaPound. For 10 points, name this loosely defined ideology opposed by antifa ("an-TEE-fuh").
tossups.answer: fascism [or fascismo; or word forms; accept neo-fascism; accept "Ur-Fascism"; prompt on ethno-nationalism or ultra-nationalism or far-right-wing or authoritarianism or totalitarianism or similar; accept Third Position or Terza Posizione or Troisième voie before read; prompt on Third Way; prompt on Nazism or national socialism or Nationalsozialismus; accept The Anatomy of Fascism or The Nature of Fascism]

tossups.question: Dan Gettinger founded an interdisciplinary center to study this technology at Bard College. In 2017, Kevin Finisterre found a backdoor in software for some of these devices that could be accessed with the eyebrow-raising username spy.liu. Nicholas Horbaczewski founded a company that uses this technology for sporting purposes that now awards a 2 –million-dollar prize to the best AI-powered implementations. One of the few American startups to find success with this technology is Zipline, which has prototyped using it in (*) Rwanda for medical purposes; the consumer market for this tech is largely dominated by China's DJI. In 2016, Chuck Schumer sponsored a bill mandating that this technology include geofencing. In 2018, flights were cancelled due to the presence of one of these devices near Gatwick Airport. For 10 points, Predators are examples of what unmanned flying devices?
tossups.answer: drones [or UAV; or delivery drones; or quadcopters; or unmanned aerial vehicle; or uncrewed aerial vehicle; accept answers like drone software; prompt on planes or aerial vehicles or helicopters or weapons or autonomous vehicles]

tossups.question: In 2019, a new upper limit on these physical quantities was determined by Germany's KATRIN project. Off-diagonal elements of a 2×2 ("two-by-two") matrix containing these quantitities equal the geometric mean of the diagonal elements, which may or may not be Majorana ("mah-yo-RAH-na") terms. The spectrum of values for these quantities may follow a normal or inverted hierarchy. Some of these physical quantities yet to be observed would require couplings that break GUT symmetry, as explained by the (*) "seesaw mechanism." Non-zero values of these quantities are necessary for a form of double beta decay that violates lepton number. Dark matter may be explained if these quantities equal even a few keV ("K-E-V") for unobserved right-handed "sterile" particles. For 10 points, Super-Kamiokande found the first non-zero values of what quantities generated by the Higgs mechanism by observing a certain lepton's flavor oscillations?
tossups.answer: non-zero neutrino masses [or masses of neutrinos; accept energy of neutrinos or neutrino energy; prompt on mass or Majorana mass terms or energy by asking "of what?"; prompt on masses of leptons or masses of fermions; accept the neutrino mass matrix]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. In the UK, the rights of this general class of people are promoted by a commission that was supervised until 2019 by Lady Helen Newlove. A Clinton-era "Clarification Act" granted new rights to these people in response to the strict policies of Richard Matsch. Many states have passed laws based on a pioneering California "bill of rights" for these people named for Marsy Nicholas. Stephanie Roper co-named a 2004 federal bill that granted these people rights of notification and non-exclusion. John Ashcroft set up a CCTV feed for a group of these people in Oklahoma. In 2018, Rosemarie Aquilina unusually allowed 156 of these people to read (*) impact statements. These people generally have a greater say and higher satisfaction rates in systems that practice restorative justice. For 10 points, identify these people who are often granted restitution at a trial.
tossups.answer: crime victims [or relatives of crime victims; or survivors of crime; accept anything involving people who are on the receiving end of any type of crime; accept more specific answers like victims of sexual assault or victims of terrorism; accept victim impact statements; accept Victims' Commissioner; prompt on athletes or women by asking “what else do they have in common?”]

tossups.question: In one book, this author recounted spending a New Year's Eve writing a hecatomb ("HECK-uh-toom") for Roberto Bolaño to thank Bolaño for having written 2666 ("26-66"). Reviewer Ken Tucker complained about "another one of [this author's] damn dreams" interrupting the narrative in a book that heavily features a character named Ernest. In an earlier book, this one-time resident of the Chelsea Hotel described making a 1973 pilgrimage to visit the grave of Arthur Rimbaud. Several of this woman's black-and-white Polaroids are reproduced in another memoir that touches on the 1994 death of her husband, Fred. This woman wrote Year of the Monkey and (*) M Train as follow-ups to a National Book Award-winning memoir that describes her long friendship with Robert Mapplethorpe. For 10 points, name this author of Just Kids, who broke onto the New York punk scene in the 1970s with her album Horses.
tossups.answer: Patti Smith [or Patricia Lee Smith]

tossups.question: Flautist James Galway played with this orchestra for the 1993 televised miniseries Concerto! This orchestra recorded Alexandre Desplat's ("dess-PLAH’s") scores for A Better Life, The Imitation Game, and Zero Dark Thirty. The first album from this orchestra's Live label was a recording of Les Troyens ("lay twah-YANN"), which was made by the independent chorus of 150 amateurs affiliated with it. This orchestra frequently hosts open rehearsals in St. Luke's church. In 1995, it premiered (*) Michael Tippett's final major piece, The Rose Lake, under its longtime conductor Colin Davis. This orchestra performed the national anthems of Brazil, Cyprus, and Uganda at the closing ceremony of the 2012 Summer Olympics. Like the BBC Orchestra, its main performance venue is Barbican Hall. For 10 points, since 2017, Simon Rattle has directed what foremost British orchestra?
tossups.answer: London Symphony Orchestra [or LSO; prompt on London; do not accept "London Philharmonic Orchestra" or "London Sinfonietta" or "BBC Symphony Orchestra"; accept London Symphony Chorus or LSC]

tossups.question: The group Red Canary fights for the rights of Chinese-Americans in this occupation and was formed after Yáng Sòng died in a 2017 incident involving the NYPD. In 2019, newly elected state representatives Jessica Ramos and Julia Salazar introduced a bill to loosen regulations on this profession in New York. A 2014 Canadian law regulating this profession was based on the Kvinnofrid ("KVEEN-oh-FREED") Law and is now opposed by Amnesty International. A company owned by Michael Lacey was sued under the terms of the (*) FOSTA-SESTA law regulating online advertisements from people in this profession, who are regulated by Scandinavia's "Nordic Model." Prior to 2017, people in this job prominently advertised on Backpage. For "stag do" parties, British men often travel to hire someone in this profession in Amsterdam. For 10 points, name these people who work in red-light districts.
tossups.answer: sex workers [or prostitutes; accept sensual massage parlor workers; do not accept answers like "adult film stars" or "porn stars"]

tossups.question: In 2013, carbon dioxide leaked out of an abandoned mine for this resource and caused a "sleeping sickness" in Kalachi and Krasnogorsk. Soldiers found this resource in "black goo" at the K2 air base. Japan and Korea are big buyers of this resource from the Navoi and Namangan regions in contracts negotiated by Shavkat Mirziyoyev. COMINAK and Areva mined this resource near the boomtown of Arlit before the industry's collapse fueled the Tuareg rebellion. The state-owned firm (*) Kazatomprom processes this resource in Kazakhstan. A new law ordered the processing of this resource at Fordow after the 2020 assassination of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh. In 2001, Italy's SISMI released forged documents alleging that Saddam Hussein tried to buy this element from Niger. For 10 points, what element's ores are recovered as yellowcake to prepare nuclear fuel?
tossups.answer: uranium [or U; accept yellowcake before read; accept pitchblende or uranium dioxide or uranium(IV) oxide or UO2 or urania or uranous oxide or other uranium compounds; accept enriched uranium]

tossups.question: The Clothworkers' Company commissioned this artist to turn his The Caged Bird's Song into a tapestry for the 2017 Weaving Magic exhibition at London's National Gallery. A bead-filled multimedia work by this artist features stars of Blaxploitation films with afros clumsily added to their heads. Responding to a "kid [who] had been killed by white racists," this artist adopted a Bob Marley title for his painting of a weeping Doreen Lawrence. Dennis Heiner threw white paint onto the most famous painting of this artist of (*) No Woman No Cry. Like his friend Peter Doig, he now lives on Trinidad. A work that this artist made for Sensation featured flies constructed from vaginas cut out of magazines behind the title religious figure. For 10 points, name this British artist whose The Holy Virgin Mary attracted criticism from Rudy Giuliani for being made from elephant dung.
tossups.answer: Chris Ofili [or Christopher Ofili]

tossups.question: Specific term required. Kevin Hassett was heavily lobbied to include support for these initiatives in one bill by Napster tech bro Sean Parker, although the resulting bill explicitly disallowed massage parlors. A ProPublica story documented how an error at the Treasury Department involving I-395 allowed Kevin Plank to qualify for one of these initiatives thanks to an earlier program. These initiatives were created by legislation sponsored by South Carolina Senator (*) Tim Scott and Cory Booker. Under Armour has tied its Port Covington project to one of these initiatives via "the most valuable parking space in America." If approved prior to 2019, investors in these places could defer 15% of their capital gain taxes. For 10 points, name these regions created by the 2017 tax reform bill ostensibly to secure investment in under-funded census tracts.
tossups.answer: opportunity zones

tossups.question: Marcy Whitebook found that wages in these programs are "STILL unlivable," revisiting a landmark 1989 study of five cities staffing these programs that she also used to rate the effects of their FIDCR ratios. The 1998 New Jersey case Abbott v. Burke created some of these programs that paid an unusually high average salary of 55,000 dollars per year. Longitudinal studies of these programs by Rutgers NIEER director W. Steven Barnett have upheld the HighScope approach pioneered by Ypsilanti's (*) Perry Project. In the 1970s, UNC's Frank Porter Graham Institute experimented with these programs in the Abecedarian ("A-B-C-darian") Project. Germany's state-funded program of this type, Kita, often only charges for meals. New York's free, "universal" program of this kind was a signature policy of Bill de Blasio. For 10 points, Early Head Start funds what programs for children who are too young for elementary school?
tossups.answer: preschools [or pre-K; or pre-kindergarten; or nursery schools; or play schools; or early childhood education programs; accept daycares; prompt on schools or private schools or education or similar; do not accept or prompt on "kindergarten"; accept childcare; accept Abbott preschool program or Perry Preschool Project; accept Kindertagesstätte or Kindertageseinrichtung] (The NIEER is the National Institute for Early Education Research. FIDCR is Federal Interagency Day Care Requirements.)

tossups.question: Nina is cut out of inheriting one of these organizations by her father, Worthington Gill, in Sergio de la Pava's novel Lost Empress. Employees of one of these organizations are described as "industrial-sized humans" in a novel whose protagonist falls in love with Faison. Mango, Crack, and others are offered a low-ball movie deal by Norm Oglesby, the owner of one of these organizations, in a novel that was adapted into a film shot in 120 frames per second by (*) Ang Lee. One of these organizations honors the Bravo Squad at a Destiny's Child concert in a Ben Fountain novel centering on Billy Lynn. Boobie Miles gets injured in a H. G. Bissinger book centering on a high school example of these organizations in Odessa, Texas, that was turned into a TV show starring Kyle Chandler. For 10 points, name these organizations chronicled in books like Friday Night Lights.
tossups.answer: American football teams [accept NFL teams; accept high school football teams; prompt on sports teams or sports organizations] (The Ben Fountain novel and Ang Lee film is Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk.)

bonuses.leadin: This artist's posthumously published memoir begins with his mother "beating the hell out of [him]" for donning his sister's dress at age 4. For 10 points each:
answer: Bill Cunningham [or William John Cunningham Jr.]
The New York Times [prompt on The Times]
a subway car [or a train; or the motorman's booth of a subway car; or subway station; or equivalents]
parts: Name this author of Fashion Climbing. A 2018 exhibit "Celebrating" this photographer includes the Schwinn bicycle that he used to capture his street fashion photos.
Cunningham was a photographer for the Style section of this major newspaper, which didn't start printing color photos until 1997.

An iconic Cunningham image depicts fellow photographer Editta Sherman seated and dressed to the nines in one of these locations. Christopher Bonanos's biography Flash relates how Weegee first thought to develop photo negatives in one of these places after a World Series game.

bonuses.leadin: After several patrons fall ill in a nightclub, this "magniloquent spoony" writer realizes that he is boring them to death. For 10 points each:
answer: Arthur Less [or Arthur Less]
Pulitzer Prizes [accept Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]
Italian [or italiano] (The Story of the Lost Child is the last entry in the Neapolitan Novels by Elena Ferrante.)
parts: Identify this mediocre author and title character of a 2017 novel who accepts a series of visiting professorships and speaking gigs to avoid the wedding of his ex-lover.

Another of Arthur Less's lovers, the Russian River School poet Robert Brownburn, wins one of these awards. In the real world, Andrew Sean Greer's novel Less won one of these awards, which are named for the owner of the New York World.

A "super translation" into this language makes one of Less's novels much better received than the English edition. Ann Goldstein has translated novels such as The Story of the Lost Child from this language.

bonuses.leadin: This practice was not criminalized in Mauritania until 2007, and according to several human rights groups, it is still rampant in that country. For 10 points each:
answer: slavery [or enslavement; prompt on forced labor]
Haratin ("ha-ra-TEEN") [or Haratines; or Hartani]
The Philippines [or Republic of the Philippines; or Filipinas; or Republika ng Pilipinas]
parts: Identify this practice often done in conjunction with human trafficking and forced sex work.

The Beydane ("bay-DAHN") often refer to this largest group of people in Mauritania as "Black Moors" or "Black Arabs." Messaoud Ould Boulkheir's ("mess-OOD oold bool-HAIR’s") El Hor organization agitates for improved conditions for this group.
A viral Atlantic essay titled "My Family's Slave" described the author's family enslaving "Lola," a woman originally from this country.

bonuses.leadin: Whole Earth Catalog editor Steward Brand hailed this group for "inventing the future" after visiting in 1986. For 10 points each:
answer: MIT Media Lab [prompt on MIT or Massachusetts Institute of Technology]

gene drives [prompt on genetic engineering or similar answers; prompt on using CRISPR or clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats or gene knockout or other answers about manipulating genes]
Drosophila [or fruit flies; accept Sophophora; accept specific species like Drosophila melanogaster]
parts: Name this research group housed in the Wiesner Building. "Open Ocean" and "Community Biotechnology" initiatives were launched by this group, whose director Joi Ito resigned ignominiously in 2019.
Kevin Esvelt's group at the Media Lab developed "daisy" systems to safely test these things. A 2003 paper by Austin Burt proposed a natural homing endonuclease to create these things.

To limit off-target gene drive spread, researchers have proposed biocontrol sterilization with the reproductive parasite Wolbachia. Wolbachia is also a normal symbiont of this iconic genus of lab insect, whose mutants are catalogued on FlyBase.

bonuses.leadin: Because Chuck Palahniuk ("PAUL-uh-nik") wrote the intro to this author's novelization of a Freud case study, Dora: A Headcase, many reviewers dubbed it the "female Fight Club." For 10 points each:
answer: Lidia Yuknavitch
Andy Warhol [or Andy Warhola]
Chuck Klosterman [or Charles John Klosterman]
parts: Name this author of The Book of Joan who described her relationship with Ken Kesey ("KEE-zee") in her memoir The Chronology of Water.

In her TED Talk "The Beauty of Being a Misfit," Yuknavitch recounts winning a short story contest and meeting Lynne Tillman as part of the prize. Tillman's The Velvet Years is a history of this Pop artist's Factory.

Yuknavitch followed up her TED Talk with a "Misfit's Manifesto." In 2003, this author published a "Low Culture Manifesto" titled Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs that examined subjects like the Pamela Anderson sex tape.

bonuses.leadin: Ài Wèiwèi created 3,200 porcelain replicas of these animals to protest the demolition of his Shànghǎi studio. For 10 points each:
answer: river crabs [or héxiè; accept other names such as hairy crabs; or mitten crabs; prompt on crustaceans or arthropods or other non-specific answers]
rabbits [or bunny rabbits; or hares; or leporids; accept lagomorphs]
Winnie-the-Pooh [or Winnie-the-Pooh & Pals; or Pooh Bear]
parts: Name these animals used to mock Hú Jǐntāo's "Harmonious Society" since they sound like "harmony" in Chinese. The mythical Grass Mud Horse, or Cǎonímǎ, battles these animals, which are sold live in vending machines in Chinese metro stations in autumn.

Chinese women used emoji of rice and this animal to talk about #MeToo, since their characters are pronounced "mǐ tù." A different character meaning "vomit" is also pronounced "tù," so these animals represent bulimic women on WeChat.
Chinese censors banned this franchise after memes compared Xí Jìnpíng to the central bear, with Barack Obama as Tigger and Shinzo Abe as Eeyore.

bonuses.leadin: This kind of policy is being tested in the Swiss town of Rheinau ("RHINE-ow"). For 10 points each:
answer: universal basic income [or UBI or guaranteed income or minimum income or citizen's income or basic living stipend or universal demogrant; prompt on income or pension]
test prep [accept answers indicating preparing or studying for standardized tests or exams; prompt on tutoring]
Andrew Ng ("ing") [or Andrew Yan-Tak Ng]
parts: Identify this kind of policy that Finland also experimented with in 2017–2018. One of these policies called the "Freedom Dividend" was the signature policy of Andrew Yang's 2020 campaign.
Yang's other accomplishments include co-founding a company named for Manhattan that provides this service. This is also the main service provided by Magoosh.

Yang became a UBI evangelist after reading a book by Martin Ford. Another Ford book profiles leading AI practitioners, such as this co-founder of Coursera and chief scientist at Bǎidù, whose applied AI course at Stanford is one of the most popular on the Internet.

bonuses.leadin: Don't know what to do with your old industrial building? Turn it into an art museum! For 10 points each:
answer: Tate Modern [prompt on the Tate; do not accept "Tate Britain"]
oil tanks [or oil depot; or tank farm; accept Tank Shànghăi; prompt on oil facility; do not accept or prompt on "oil refinery"]
South Africa [or Republic of South Africa; or RSA; or iRiphabhuliki yase Ningizimu Afrika; or iRiphabliki yom Zantsi Afrika; or Republiek van Suid-Afrika; or similar names from other languages]
parts: One of the most famous such conversions is this large London gallery that used to be the Bankside Power Station. Tino Sehgal and Tacita Dean have staged exhibitions in its Turbine Hall.

Qiáo Zhìbīng ("ch’yao jurr-bing"), the "Karaoke King" of Shànghăi, converted five of these industrial structures into an art museum and recreation facility. Two of these structures double as performance spaces at the Tate Modern.

The Grain Silo Complex, once the tallest structure in this country, was recently converted by Jochen Zeitz ("YO-khen ZYTES") into a contemporary art museum. The Ponte City Tower was once a "vertical slum" in this country.

bonuses.leadin: In an article for The Toast, this linguist "explains the grammar of Doge. Wow." For 10 points each:
answer: Gretchen McCulloch

vocal fry register [or creakiness; or creaky voice; or pulse register/phonation; or croakiness; or laryngealization or word forms; or glottal fry; or glottal rattle; or glottal scrape; or Strohbass; accept popcorning]
exclamation points! [or exclamation marks!; accept bangs!]
parts: Name this Canadian linguist who co-hosts the podcast Lingthusiasm with Lauren Gawne. She tracked the rise of memes, all-caps text, emoji as digital gestures, and other features of online communication in the book Because Internet.

McCulloch has defended this register as a typical example of linguistic innovation by teen girls. Penny Eckert found that people under 40 associated authority with this register, which involves an articulation similar to the phenomenon of stød in Danish.

Teen girls have also been mocked for using these punctuation marks excessively, but McCulloch notes that they are now standard markers of politeness in emails. The brand Chips Ahoy uses this punctuation in its name.

bonuses.leadin: As part of an unusual settlement in a rate raising case, Verizon paid 15 million dollars to increase the number of these things in rural West Virginia. For 10 points each:
answer: street addresses [or house numbers; or building numbers; or postal addresses]
Florence [or Firenze]
What3Words [or What3Words Limited]
parts: Identify these things that are rarely used on Native American reservations, causing problems for some voters in North Dakota in 2018. Mayors in rural France have been pressured to reform these things to no longer be based on metric distance from the town square.
This city confusingly has red and black addresses: one is residential, the other commercial. This city's Accademia, which houses Michelangelo's David, is located on the Via Ricasoli.
This London-based company seeks to reform street addresses with a geocode system that produces addresses like "tubes.page.forced" for any region on Earth.

bonuses.leadin: Crispin Wright outlined a pluralist theory of this concept in a book named for it and "Objectivity." For 10 points each:
answer: truth [accept semantic truth; accept Truth and Objectivity; accept The Death of Truth]
Hannah Arendt [or Hannah Arendt Bluecher; or Johanna "Hannah" Cohn Arendt; accept The Three Escapes of Hannah Arendt: A Tyranny of Truth]
Ágnes Heller
parts: Name this concept whose "semantic" form was defended by Jan Woleński. Michiko Kakutani's book on "The Death of [this concept]" drew heavily on The Origins of Totalitarianism.

"A tyranny of truth" is the subtitle of Ken Krimstein's 2018 comic about this philosopher, who inspired a 2012 Margarethe von Trotta film and the 2015 documentary Vita Activa. Bettina Stangneth ("SHTONG-nate") responded to her in Eichmann Before Jerusalem.

The first Hannah Arendt Award went to this Budapest School philosopher, who died in 2019. She outlined society's "system of needs" in The Theory of Need in Marx and described the "in-itself" in Everyday Life.

bonuses.leadin: Amy Hagstrom Miller, the subject of a prominent Supreme Court case in 2016, was evicted by her landlord in favor of one of these institutions that offered five years' worth of rent up front. For 10 points each:
answer: crisis pregnancy center [or CPC; or pregnancy resource center; or PRC] (The case was Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt.)
Texas [or TX]
TRAP Laws [accept targeted restrictions on abortion providers]
parts: Identify these non-profits that are often tied to larger groups like Care Net and Heartbeat International. They commonly offer free sonograms to discourage women from having abortions.
Miller's Whole Woman's Health abortion clinic was in the capital of this state. Wendy Davis filibustered an anti-abortion bill in this state before running against Greg Abbott for governor.
Pro-life advocates have passed several laws known by this four-letter acronym that make it harder to run abortion clinics by, for example, requiring clinics to qualify as surgery centers.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Rupert Sheldrake's pseudoscience career, for 10 points each.
answer: magnetoreception [or magnetoception; or magnetosensing; accept anything about sensing Earth's magnetic field or magnetism]
protein crystallization [or word forms like getting a crystal structure; accept X-ray crystallography]
foveated imaging systems [or word forms; accept fovea centralis]
parts: Sheldrake has asserted that homing pigeons have collective memory. A contentious 2015 Nature Materials paper claimed to discover the cryptochrome complex that controls this sense that they use for homing.

Sheldrake used "morphogenesis" to try to explain why this task gets easier over time. This frustrating process involves supersaturating a pure protein sample to obtain an X-ray image of its structure.

Sheldrake claims that people sense they are being stared at with "morphic resonance." Real research on eye movements has contributed to these imaging systems, which save bandwidth by decreasing resolution as a function of eccentricity to mimic the human eye.

bonuses.leadin: A café worker in this musical starts singing a lullaby to his son, but soon starts singing about "the loser and the loser's wife." For 10 points each:
answer: The Band's Visit
Tel Aviv [accept Gush Dan]
Ireland [or Republic of Ireland; or Éire; or Poblacht na hÉireann] (The singer was Brendan Graham.)
parts: Name this musical whose song "Welcome to Nowhere" distinguishes between a city with "lots of fun, lots of art, lots of culture" "with a P" and a similar-sounding town "with a B" that is "basically bleak and beige."

The fun city alluded to in The Band's Visit, Petah Tikva ("PET-ahkh TICK-va"), lies in the metro area of this city. After Netta's song "Toy" won Eurovision in 2018, the 2019 contest was held in this Israeli cultural capital.

The Tel Aviv Eurovision was protested by a singer from this country who won it in 1994 for "Rock 'n' Roll Kids." This country's "shoegazing" band My Bloody Valentine developed the "glide guitar" technique.

bonuses.leadin: Visitors to North American caves must clean their shoes and gear to avoid spreading spores that transmit this disease. For 10 points each:
answer: white-nose syndrome [or WNS]
Pinnacles National Park
Indiana [or IN; accept Indiana Dunes National Park]
parts: Name this disease that can be treated by the bacterium Rhodococcus. This disease has devastated bats infected by the psychrophilic fungus Pseudogymnoascus destructans ("pseudo-gymno-ascus destruct-ans").

White-nose syndrome has luckily not spread to this national park, where many bats inhabit unique talus caves. This national park supports hundreds of bee species and provides a key release site for California condor recovery.

Pinnacles became a national park six years before this state's sand dunes on Lake Michigan. The Lucas Oil Stadium and Artsgarden were recently built in this state's capital, which hosts an annual motorsports race.

bonuses.leadin: In 2020, this magazine's annual queer issue featured a Cebuano story about a tattoo addict by R. Joseph Dazo. For 10 points each:
answer: Words Without Borders [or WWB]
México [or Estados Unidos Mexicanos; or United Mexican States]
Gothic novels [accept Mexican Gothic; accept Southern Gothic or Southern Ontario Gothic]
parts: Name this online magazine for literature in translation. This magazine's monthly themed issues have included "Dalit Literature in Hindi" and "Contemporary Guaraní Poetry."

Carmen Boullosa ("bo-YO-sa") edited an issue of Words Without Borders about a conflict in this country. Valeria Luiselli wrote The Story of My Teeth in collaboration with a juice factory in this country, where Jorge Volpi contributed to the "Crack Manifesto."

A 2020 novel by Silvia Moreno-Garcia takes place in a '50s-era Mexico inflected by this genre. The "Southern Ontario" style of this genre plays on its "Southern" subgenre attributed to Carson McCullers.

bonuses.leadin: Sociologist Nathalie E. Paton documented common tropes in the videos posted prior to these events. For 10 points each:
answer: mass school shootings [prompt on mass shootings or murders or massacres]
Jack Thompson [or John Bruce Thompson]
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [or CDC]
parts: Identify these tragic events. A 2002 Michael Moore documentary explored what caused Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold to carry out one of these actions.

This now-disbarred lawyer sued the producers of 1997's The Basketball Diaries for supposedly causing Michael Carneal to shoot up a prayer group. In 2007, TakeTwo tried to prevent this man from suing the company over Grand Theft Auto.
This organization, led during much of the Trump era by Robert Redfield, was barred from doing research on gun control via the 1996 Dickey Amendment.

bonuses.leadin: In an episode of the Comedy Central program Corporate that centers on this software, Matt creates a pitch for the CIA. For 10 points each:
answer: Microsoft PowerPoint [prompt on Microsoft Office]
An Inconvenient Truth (The song was Melissa Etheridge's "I Need to Wake Up.")
David Byrne ("burn")
parts: Identify this software, the most popular in a category that also includes Prezi and Keynote.
In several scenes of this documentary, the protagonist can be seen revising his slides in Keynote. This documentary, which was produced by Laurie David, unusually won an Oscar for Best Original Song.

In 2005, this artist gave a somewhat sarcastic talk at Berkeley titled "I Love PowerPoint." This artist discussed how the acoustics of nightclubs influenced the sound of rock music in his 2012 book How Music Works.

bonuses.leadin: This language's developer Fernando Pérez spun off one of its shells into the language-agnostic Project Jupyter ("Jupiter"). For 10 points each:
answer: Python [accept iPython]
conda [or Anaconda; accept Miniconda]
pip [or pip installs packages]
parts: Name this programming language whose "benevolent dictator for life," Guido van Rossum, stepped down in 2018. Data scientists have widely adopted the pandas library for this language, which students often learn with the environment IDLE.
Data scientists often use packages from this Python and R distribution. Users can make a virtual environment by typing this package manager's name followed by "create."

Conda's install tool is an alternative to this popular command-line Python package installer system whose short name is a recursive acronym. It's common to use a "requirements.txt" file with this tool.

bonuses.leadin: This country was rocked by the Narcoindultos scandal, when one of its former presidents issued hundreds of commutations and pardons to convicted drug dealers. For 10 points each:
answer: Peru [or Republic of Peru; or República del Perú]
Keiko Fujimori [or Keiko Sofía Fujimori Higuchi; or Señora K]
Odebrecht S.A.
parts: Name this country whose exiled former President Alejandro Toledo was arrested in California for public intoxication in 2019. In that same year, another of its former presidents committed suicide.
Peruvian prosecutors arrested this ex-First Lady in 2018 on money laundering charges. Her father, a former President, fled to Japan to try to beat human rights charges.

Keiko Fujimori is one of many Peruvian politicians alleged to have taken bribes from this Brazilian conglomerate. Marcelo, a member of this company's eponymous family, was arrested in Operation Car Wash.
